entry.title: A Post Quantum Migration Proposal
entry.summary:
The correspondence from the Bitcoin Development Mailing List touches on the theoretical capabilities of analog and quantum computers in breaking cryptographic primitives, a subject of much speculation within the tech community. The discussion acknowledges that while algorithms exist that could theoretically compromise cryptographic systems given sufficiently advanced analog or quantum computing technology, such advancements remain firmly in the realm of theory rather than practice. The skepticism towards the current state of quantum computing is evident, with it being noted that despite claims of progress, no one has demonstrated a quantum computer capable of affecting cryptography in any meaningful way. The performance of existing quantum hardware in tasks relevant to cryptography is described as inadequate, casting doubt on their potential to pose a real threat to digital security infrastructures anytime soon.
Moreover, the email articulates a broader skepticism within parts of the physics community regarding the physical feasibility of such computing technologies. Despite the enthusiasm of some segments of the scientific community about the prospects of quantum computing, there remains a significant skepticism about whether these technologies can ever be realized in a manner that would impact cryptographic practices. This skepticism extends to the notion of actively taking measures against the theoretical threat posed by these technologies, such as freezing digital assets. The message implies that until there is clear, tangible progress in quantum computing that poses a genuine threat to cryptography, precautionary actions like freezing people's coins remain unjustified.
For further reading on these topics, the email provides a link to [Peter Todd's website](https://petertodd.org), suggesting that the reader can find more in-depth discussions and analyses there. This invitation to explore additional resources underscores the complexity of the issues at hand and the ongoing nature of the debate surrounding the future impact of quantum computing on cryptography.
